Abashi?
EverQuest: General EverQuest: Abashi?
  

Abashi Love

Friday, August 18, 2000 - 05:31 pm
Abashi
Station Member posted 08-17-2000 11:56 PM
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I've noticed that many of the responses to the thread "why camp" still
suggest randomizing loot, beyond that which is present in Kunark.
Certainly in Kunark, we've been trying contextual randomness
(randomness that makes sense in the environment) on good loot, while
leaving the best loot on standard "boss" NPCs. We've been fairly happy
with the results, as it allows the casual player a good chance to pick
up loot that will work for their class without "requiring" them to
camp.
Still, many continue to suggest that we further randomize loot. I'd
like to map out an example that shows why this isn't always the best
answer. I think that the biggest misconception that I see here in
regards to random loot is that the items will be more available. This
isn't the case, as we still need to control the rate at which items
enter the world. Randomizing loot isn't going to cause this rate to
increase.

Let's say that CoolItem has a 20% chance to drop off of BossFrog in
Lower Guk, who spawns 100% of the time on a 20 minute timer. This
means that in two hours (six spawns, assuming he were killed instantly
after spawning, which is close enough to the case), the frog would
have just under a 74% chance of dropping CoolItem at least once. A
group choosing to camp BossFrog would have a pretty good chance of
getting 1 item in two hours.

Now, lets say that it was random. We can't increase the overall rate
that CoolItem enters the world. So lets say that we give 20 frogs
(still on a 20 minute timer) a 1% chance of dropping the item. Anyone
care to guess how many of *these* frogs you have to kill to have the
same 74% chance of getting the item? 135. Assuming the dungeon was
completely camped, and that you could only kill one frog every 20
minutes, it would take 45 hours to have a 74% chance of getting the
item. Suppose the dungeon isn't that crowded and you can take a whole
room with 4 frogs in it every 20 minutes, it would still take 135
frogs to get that 74% chance, taking over 11 hours. The single-spawn
20% drop frog would have a 67% chance of dropping at least 6 during
that time.

This same logic follows for suggestions that have the creature spawn
in any number of random locations. If we have 20 places that BossFrog
spawns, on a 1% spawn, and give him a 100% chance of dropping the
item, we're still at 135 Frogs to get that 74% chance of him spawning.

As you can see, the level of randomness that some people are
suggesting would create more frustration than people currently cite.

-Gordon
